The El Niño-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) is a recurring climate phenomenon characterized by fluctuations in tropical Pacific Ocean temperatures, alternating between warm El Niño and cold La Niña conditions. It is a major driver of climate variability, leading to disasters such as floods, droughts, and heavy rains in various regions worldwide, and has implications for agriculture and public health. Despite its importance, long-term ENSO forecasts have traditionally been challenging due to its complex nature and high variability.

Recent studies suggest that more frequent, long-term, or variable El Niño conditions may result from global warming caused by greenhouse gases, but the extent of climate change's influence on ENSO is still unknown and debated. This work proposes the first application of graph neural networks to seasonal forecasting and presents initial results that outperform existing dynamical and deep learning ENSO models for 1 and 3-month lead times.

The forecasting methods in use can be broadly classified into dynamical and statistical systems. Dynamical systems are based on physical processes and climate models, while statistical systems are data-driven, including machine learning approaches. Recent deep learning methods have successfully forecasted ENSO up to 1 year ahead and up to 1.5 years ahead, outperforming state-of-the-art dynamical methods. These methods project the Oceanic Niño Index (ONI) for various lead times, using either the ONI index time series or sea surface temperature (SST) and heat content anomaly maps as input.

Most statistical methods can only predict the single-valued index, an averaged metric over SST anomalies that does not convey more zonal information. A notable exception uses an encoder-decoder approach. Climate networks, which stem from the field of complex networks, have been used to detect and characterize SST teleconnections and to project ENSO up to 1 year prior. Graph neural networks have recently been applied to various fields, including earthquake source detection, power outage prediction, and wind-farm power estimation. Our approach builds on the climate network's precedent of describing climate as a network of nodes related by non-local connections, and we expect that spatiotemporal GNNs will be able to learn the large-scale, spatiotemporal patterns indicative of ENSO.

The proposed method uses spatiotemporal Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) to forecast ENSO at long lead times, finer granularity, and improved predictive skill than current state-of-the-art methods. The explicit modeling of information flow via edges may also allow for more interpretable forecasts. Preliminary results are promising and outperform state-of-the-art systems for projections 1 and 3 months ahead.
